item.title: atomic
item.description:
In programming, anÂ atomicÂ action is one that effectively happens all at once.

it either happens completely, or it doesn’t happen at all.

some method you can consider as atomic

  • Reads and writes are atomic for reference variables and for most primitive variables (all types exceptÂ longÂ andÂ double).

  • Reads and writes are atomic forÂ allÂ variables declaredÂ volatile

Atomic actions cannot be interleaved, so they can be used without fear of thread interference.

item.title: deadlock
item.description:
DeadlockÂ describes a situation where two or more threads are blocked forever, waiting for each other.

Alphonse and Gaston are friends, and great believers in courtesy. A strict rule of courtesy is that when you bow to a friend, you must remain bowed until your friend has a chance to return the bow. Unfortunately, this rule does not account for the possibility that two friends might bow to each other at the same time. This example application followed models this possibility:

item.title: Difference between run() and start()
item.description:
Â the two most significant methods of multithreading are start() and run().

major differences

1. Thread creation

However, if we call the run() function directly, no new thread is generated, and the run() method is executed as a normal method call on the current calling thread, with no multi-threading

2. Multiple invocation

Â start() method cannot be performed again without throwing anIllegalStateException Â  Â It isÂ never legal to start a thread more than once Â  Â  In particular, a thread may not be restarted once it has completed execution. Â

item.title: Liveness
item.description: A concurrent application’s ability to execute in a timely manner is known as its liveness. This section describes the most common kind of liveness problem, [[deadlock]], and goes on to briefly describe two other liveness problems, starvation and livelock.

item.title: Memory Consistency Errors
item.description:
What is a Memory Consistency Errors?

one of Thread most 3 errors

different threads haveÂ inconsistent viewsÂ of what should be the same data

The causes of memory consistency errors are complex, Fortunately, we don’t have to need a detailed understanding of these causes.

we need a strategy for avoiding them.

The key to avoid MC errors is understanding Happen-before relationship

Happen-before

a relationship guarantee memory writes by one specific statement are visible to another specific statement

class DatabaseCreator {
    private static final String URL = "jdbc:mysql://localhost:3306/?useSSL=false&serverTimezone=UTC";
    private static final String USER = "root";
    private static final String PASSWORD = "Codingmore123";
    private static final String DATABASE_NAME = "pai_coding";

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        try (Connection conn = DriverManager.getConnection(URL, USER, PASSWORD);
             Statement stmt = conn.createStatement()) {

            if (!databaseExists(conn, DATABASE_NAME)) {
                stmt.executeUpdate("CREATE DATABASE IF NOT EXISTS " + DATABASE_NAME);
                System.out.println("æ•°æ®åº“åˆ›å»ºæˆåŠŸ");
            } else {
                System.out.println("æ•°æ®åº“å·²ç»å­˜åœ¨");
            }
        } catch (SQLException e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        }
    }

    private static boolean databaseExists(Connection conn, String dbName) throws SQLException {
        ResultSet resultSet = conn.getMetaData().getCatalogs();

        while (resultSet.next()) {
            if (dbName.equals(resultSet.getString(1))) {
                return true;
            }
        }

        return false;
    }
}

The Java programming language provides two basic synchronization idioms:Â 

synchronized methodsÂ andÂ synchronized statements.

we are talking about synchronization idioms

synchronization idioms

To make a method synchronized, simply add theÂ synchronizedÂ keyword to its declaration:

public class SynchronizedCounter {
    private int c = 0;

    public synchronized void increment() {
        c++;
    }

    public synchronized void decrement() {
        c--;
    }

    public synchronized int value() {
        return c;
    }
}

SynchronizationÂ is crucial for ensuring that multiple threads operate safely on shared resources. WithoutÂ *Synchronization, data inconsistency or corruption can occur when multiple threads try to access and modify shared variables simultaneously.Â In Java, it is a mechanism that ensures that only one thread can access a resource at any given time

        CountDownLatch countDownLatch = new CountDownLatch(10);

Exchanger

A synchronization point at which threads can pair and swap elements within pairs. Each thread presents some object on entry to theÂ exchangeÂ method, matches with a partner thread, and receives its partner’s object on return. An Exchanger may be viewed as a bidirectional form of aÂ SynchronousQueue. Exchangers may be useful in applications such as genetic algorithms and pipeline designs.
